document.masterDocTitle: A revision of the spider genus Echinax Deeleman-Reinhold, 2001 (Araneae: Corinnidae) in the Afrotropical Region

mods:titleInfo.mods:title: A revision of the spider genus Echinax Deeleman-Reinhold, 2001 (Araneae: Corinnidae) in the Afrotropical Region

bibRefCitation.author: Deeleman-Reinhold
bibRefCitation.refString: Deeleman-Reinhold, C. L. (2001) Forest spiders of South East Asia: with a revision of the sac and ground spiders (Araneae: Clubionidae, Corinnidae, Liocranidae, Gnaphosidae, Prodidomidae and Trochanterriidae [sic]). Brill, Leiden, 591 pp.

subSubSection.paragraph:
Type species:
Copa oxyopoides
Deeleman-Reinhold, 1995
, by original designation.

caption.paragraph:
FIGURES 1–16. Digital stereomicroscope photographs of
Echinax clara
sp. nov.
(1, 2),
E. hesperis
sp. nov.
(3, 4),
E. longespina (Simon, 1909)
(5, 6),
E. natalensis
sp. nov.
(7, 8),
E. scharffi
sp. nov.
(9, 10),
E. similis
sp. nov.
(11, 12) and
E. spatulata
sp. nov.
(13–16): 1, 3, 5, 7, 9, 11, 13. Female habitus, dorsal view. 2, 4, 6, 8, 10, 12, 14. Male habitus, dorsal view. 15. Male patella and tibia I and II, retrolateral view, indicating distal dorsal patellar spines (PS). 16. Male palpal cymbium, dorsal view, indicating modified distal setae (MDS) and spatulate setae (SS). Scale bars: 1–15 = 1.0mm, 16 = 0.1mm.

FIGURES 17–28. Scanning electron microscope photographs of
Echinax natalensis
sp. nov.
male (17, 18) and female (19–28): 17. Chelicerae, ventral view. 18, 19. Serrula. 20. Tibia I, detail of ventral spines. 21. Femur I, indicating feathery setae (FS) and erect ventral setae (EVS). 22. Same, detail of feathery setae. 23. Patella I, indicating patellar indentation (PI). 24. Same, detail of lyriform organ at proximal end of PI. 25. Metatarsus I, detail of ventral distal setae. 26. Tarsus I, trichobothrium base. 27. Same, tarsal organ. 28. Tarsus IV, tarsal claw and claw tuft.

subSubSection.paragraph:
Diagnosis.
Echinax
resembles
Copa
in general body shape, heavily spined legs and the presence of cryptic lycosiform colouration, but can be recognised from other cryptic lycosiform Castianeirinae , particularly
Copa
, by their smaller size (< 5.80 mm , almost always larger in other genera); the presence of very long leg spines distally on all patellae that are longer than the particular leg segment, and the spines on the anterior metatarsi that are longer than half the length of the particular segment (shorter than patellae and less than half metatarsi length in other genera); the AME that are 2 to 3 times ALE diameter (less than 2 times in other genera); and the carapace that is approximately 2.75–3.10 times broader than the PER (PER usually broader in other genera).

caption.paragraph:
FIGURES 29–34. Scanning electron microscope photographs of
Echinax similis
sp. nov.
female (29, 30) and male (31–34): 29. Chelicerae, anteroventral view. 30, 31. Serrula. 32. Patella I, detail of lyriform organ at proximal end of patellar indentation. 33. Tarsus IV, trichobothrium. 34. Same, tarsal claw and claw tuft.

FIGURES 35–40. Scanning electron microscope photographs of
Echinax natalensis
sp. nov.
female (35–37) and male (38–40) spinneret morphology. 35, 38. Anterior lateral spinneret. 36, 39. Posterior median spinneret. 37, 40. Posterior lateral spinneret. Abbreviations: Ac–aciniform gland spigot(s); Cy—cylindrical gland spigot(s); MAmp—major ampullate gland spigot(s); mAmp—minor ampullate gland spigot(s); n—nubbin; Pi—piriform gland spigot; Ta—tartipore.

FIGURES 41–44. Scanning electron microscope photos of
Echinax natalensis
sp. nov.
(41, 42) and
E. similis
sp. nov.
(43, 44) genitalia: 41, 43. Female epigyne, ventral view. 42. Male embolus, ventral view. 44. Tip of embolus, prolateral view.
